qas.question: Which time zone in Europe always has a one-hour lead on Central European Time?
For one hour each spring, how far ahead of Pacific Time is Mountain Time in the United States?
In 2008, what month and day did Western Australia change their clocks?
At DST in the fall, how long does it stay the same time in both Pacific and Mountain time in the United States?
In addition to much of the state of Arizona, what U.S. state does not ever change their clocks for DST?

context: Coordination strategies differ when adjacent time zones shift clocks. The European Union shifts all at once, at 01:00 UTC or 02:00 CET or 03:00 EET; for example, <a0_0>Eastern European Time<a0_0/> is always <a3_0>one hour<a3_0/> ahead of Central European Time. Most of North America shifts at 02:00 local time, so its zones do not shift at the same time; for example, Mountain Time is temporarily (for one hour) zero hours ahead of Pacific Time, instead of one hour ahead, in the autumn and <a1_0>two hours<a1_0/>, instead of one, ahead of Pacific Time in the spring. In the past, Australian districts went even further and did not always agree on start and end dates; for example, in 2008 most DST-observing areas shifted clocks forward on October 5 but Western Australia shifted on <a2_0>October 26<a2_0/>. In some cases only part of a country shifts; for example, in the US, <a4_0>Hawaii<a4_0/> and most of Arizona do not observe DST.
